text: the US Supreme Court has handed victory
to President Trump by partially allowing
his temporary ban on travelers from six
mainly Muslim majority countries to come
into effect the justices will now
consider in October whether the policy
which bans citizens for 90 days and
refugees for 120 days should be upheld
or struck down mr. Trump says the ban is
needed for national security despite
criticism that it is in violation of the
US Constitution well our correspondent
Anthony zurka is in Washington for us
and three it has been an ongoing tussle
between mr. Trump and the court so bring
us up to speed all right well what the
Supreme Court justices said was that the
ban could go into effect for individuals
in those six countries and refugees who
did not have bonafide relationships with
the United States now the court
described a bona fide relationship as
say having family members already in the
United States have some sort of an
employment agreement with a company
based in the United States or to have an
education agreement a scholarship or
admission into u.s. school so say if you
were living in Iran and you were a
student coming over to the u.s. you had
already been admitted to a school in the
US you could still enter into the
country the ban didn't apply to you but
for everyone else in those six countries
and individuals who had been granted
even refugee status and had already been
vetted the the court justices said that
Donald Trump can't essentially close the
borders to them during what they said
would be a 90-day review process and all
of us then goes on to next autumn when
the Supreme Court will take a closer
look at this case on its merits so why
the change now given that initially this
ban was knocked back well this was the
first chance for the Supreme Court to
take a look at it and if you looked at
the lower court opinions it's
interesting these court justices at the
appellate level they looked a lot at the
religion religious discrimination they
saw in the band they said that it
discriminated against Muslims they
looked at Donald Trump's tweets they
looked at his speeches they looked at
his surrogate statements the Supreme
Court justices didn't pay any attention
to that whatsoever they
looked at existing statute and
presidential power and they said that in
areas of national security that
president has sweeping powers and that
the interest in preserving the country
protecting the country outweigh any
concerns of individuals abroad who do
not have real ties to the US so now six
countries whose citizens are going to be
one could say inconvenienced if that's
not to weaker words any response yet
from those countries no response yet
it'll be interesting to see how the
Trump administration implements this how
the lower courts interpret bona fide
relationships it's a little vague the
Supreme Court ruling leaves some
flexibility what exactly constitutes a
bona fide relationship so you know
students can come in but there's no
guarantee of what type of students what
sort of what sort of schools are going
to so I think we're going to have to
wait to see how all of this plays out
the Trump administration has said that
within 72 hours of court decision they
were going to implement to re-implement
the travel ban so I think you're going
to see them act fairly quickly okay
Anthony Sokka thanks very much
